title: About
text: Hi, my name is Caroline Cummings! I am a Senior studying Computer Science with a concentration in AI. I am excited to learn about the applications of using LLMs to improve the quality and efficiency of tasks in everyday life.

title: Prompting ChatGPT for marathon training plan
text:
I‚Äôve been running consistently, but I‚Äôve never had a formal marathon plan tailored to my goals and timeframe. Hiring a coach can be expensive, and online plans are usually one-size-fits-all.
So, I decided to experiment: what if ChatGPT 5 could be my running coach?



I wanted to have the final plan customized for me based on my current fitness and lifestlye. I started off by asking ChatGPT 5 what sort of information it wanted from me in order to make my training plan.

User: I want you to be my running coach to help me train for the 2025 Philadelphia Marathon which is in 2 months. Can you give me a list of questions that you would ask me in order to formulate a customized training plan for me?

ChatGPT: Perfect! To create a customized 2-month training plan for the 2025 Philadelphia Marathon, I‚Äôd want to get a full picture of your background, goals, lifestyle, and constraints. Here‚Äôs a list of questions I‚Äôd ask you as your ‚Äúcoach‚Äù:
üèÉ Running Background

What is your current weekly mileage?
What‚Äôs the longest run you‚Äôve completed recently?
Have you ever run a marathon before? If so, what was your time/experience like?
Do you have recent race times for shorter distances (5K, 10K, half marathon)?
Do you typically run on roads, tracks, or trails?

üéØ Goals & Expectations

What is your primary goal for the Philadelphia Marathon ‚Äî finish strong, hit a specific time, or qualify for something (e.g., Boston)?
Do you have a target pace in mind for race day?
What‚Äôs more important to you: speed, endurance, or simply enjoying the experience?

üèãÔ∏è Strength & Cross Training

Do you currently do strength training or cross training (cycling, swimming, yoga, etc.)?
Are you open to incorporating strength/mobility sessions into your plan?

‚è∞ Schedule & Lifestyle

How many days per week can you realistically commit to running?
Do you prefer morning, afternoon, or evening runs?
Do you have any upcoming travel, work, or school commitments that may affect training?

ü©∫ Health & Injury History

Have you had any past or current injuries (knees, shins, ankles, hips, etc.)?
Do you have any health concerns I should keep in mind (e.g., asthma, anemia, nutrition issues)?

ü•ó Fueling & Recovery

How‚Äôs your nutrition and hydration routine right now?
Do you have experience practicing fueling (gels, chews, hydration) on long runs?
How many hours of sleep do you typically get per night?

üå¶ Race-Day Specifics

Have you run in Philadelphia before, or are you familiar with the marathon course?
Do you have gear preferences (shoes, watch, hydration belt/vest)?

üí° Personal Motivation

What motivates you most: following a structured plan, listening to your body, or running with others?
What do you hope to get out of this marathon beyond just finishing (confidence, health, community, fun)?


It gave me 22 questions to answer! I answered each of them to the best of my ability with hopes of having a very in-depth and tailored training plan.

This experiment showed me how AI can make training feel more accessible.
While it won‚Äôt replace years of coaching expertise, it‚Äôs a surprisingly motivating and structured tool.
For now, ChatGPT is my new running buddy ‚Äî and hopefully, it‚Äôll help me cross the finish line in Philadelphia this fall.

title: ChatGPT Helps Me Cut My Roommate‚Äôs Hair
text:
Cutting hair is one of those things that seems simple until you‚Äôre the one actually holding the scissors. My roommate asked me to trim and layer her long, wavy hair and I told her I‚Äôd give it a go.
So naturally, I opened ChatGPT-5 and asked it how to guide me step-by-step.




My friend asked me to cut her hair. How would you recommend I do it? She has long hair that‚Äôs slightly wavy with layers



ChatGPT gave a beginner-friendly overview: tools needed, the ‚Äúgolden rules,‚Äù and a safe method using sectioning or the ‚Äúunicorn cut.‚Äù It emphasized trimming very conservatively, keeping symmetry, and using point-cutting to soften the ends.
It told me not to use kitchen scissors. Unfortunately, those were the only scissors I had.

I uploaded a picture of my roommate‚Äôs hair from the back. I clarified that I didn‚Äôt want to do the unicorn cut.






I don‚Äôt think I want to do a unicorn cut so I think I‚Äôll section it and cut it.




ChatGPT analyzed the photo and confirmed:
The hair type (long, wavy)
Uneven ends
Recommended a 3-section method
Told me exactly how to trim the bottom, middle, and top sections safely
It was like having a virtual hairstylist supervise.

I sent another picture after I clipped her hair into multiple sections.






It outlined the steps to go from the current photo including what to do for the bottom, middle, and top sections and then doing the side + face-framing and cross-check. It also made the comment:


Just keep these rules in mind:

Bottom = blunt(ish) trim
Middle = longest/softest layers
Top = lightest, shortest layers
Point-cut everything except the bottom baseline


It adjusted its instructions based on the exact setup in the image.

I did the length trim and sent another picture of the result.






Now I want to do layers.




This is where ChatGPT-5 really shined. It told me exactly how to layer based on the photo:
Release the middle section
Cut the ‚Äúguide‚Äù layer
Elevate at 45¬∞
Trim only 1/2 inch
Use vertical point-cutting to avoid harsh lines
Then move to the top section and add only light layering

The layering was the part that I was most worried for but I followed the instructions and think my roommates hair turned out great!
Would I trust ChatGPT to cut my own hair? ‚Ä¶ Probably not.
Would I use it again to cut someone else‚Äôs hair? Absolutely.

title: Getting Started with GPT4All
text:
Local LLMs are great when you want privacy, offline access, or the freedom to experiment without an API key. GPT4All is a friendly desktop app that lets you download and chat with hundreds of open models‚Äîfrom lightweight 3‚Äì8B assistants to niche coding or multilingual variants‚Äîright on your machine.
Installing the GPT4All app typically takes less than 5 minutes and once you launch it you can explore all the models they have to offer.







Best for: Tiny footprint, quick drafts, ‚Äúalways-on‚Äù helper on modest hardware.
Why it‚Äôs neat: Strong quality for its size; offered in 4K and 128K context variants.





Best for: General chat + reasoning at 7B scale; a solid baseline many people compare against.
Note: Community-standard workhorse; the Instruct flavor is a tuned chat model.





Best for: Multilingual tasks & coding-friendly chat with modern tuning.
Why it‚Äôs neat: Qwen2/2.5 report strong results across language understanding, generation, coding, and reasoning.





Best for: Longer context experiments and a widely supported 8B option.
Trade-off: A step up in memory/compute vs.¬†7B, but you get a newer training run and longer context window.






1) Start with your hardware.

Low RAM / older CPU? Begin with Phi-3 Mini (Q4) for responsiveness.
8‚Äì16 GB+ and patient? Try Mistral 7B Instruct (Q4/Q5) or Qwen2(.5) 7B Instruct for a quality bump.
Room to spare / longer docs? Experiment with Llama-3.1-8B Instruct (longer context).

2) Match the task.

General writing/assistant: Mistral 7B, Llama-3.1-8B.
Small + snappy: Phi-3 Mini.
Multilingual/coding: Qwen2/2.5 7B.

3) Pick a quantization.

Q4 loads faster and uses less RAM; Q5 trades a bit more memory for a quality bump.
In GPT4All, you‚Äôll see these as different downloads of the same model‚Äîgrab Q4 first, upgrade if you need more fidelity.

4) Keep an eye on context length.

If you paste long readings or transcripts, prefer models that ship 8K‚Äì128K contexts (e.g., Phi-3 128K, Llama-3.1-8B).





GGUF is a compact binary format optimized for local inference (fast loading/saving) used by runners like llama.cpp. You‚Äôll see many models offered as *.gguf downloads in GPT4All‚Äôs browser and on Hugging Face. You don‚Äôt have to do anything special‚Äîjust download and run‚Äîbut it‚Äôs why these models feel snappy on CPU.





It feels slow. Try a smaller model (3‚Äì4B), a more aggressive quantization (Q4), or reduce context length in GPT4All settings.
Out-of-memory errors. Close other heavy apps, use Q4, or choose a smaller parameter count.
macOS specifics. Official docs currently list Monterey 12.6+ as the target for the macOS build, and performance is best on Apple Silicon; CPU-only still works‚Äîjust pick smaller models.
Need lots of models? GPT4All‚Äôs browser surfaces a huge catalog so you can trial multiple flavors side-by-side.

title: Comparing ChatGPT 5.0 with a Mental Health LLM
text:
I have heard of some of my friends using ChatGPT as a tool to talk to and vent their feelings. So, I was already under the assumptions that people were using LLMs as therapists.
In my book Superagency, I was excited to read about how there are models being built specifically as therapists. However, Reid Hoffman highlights the failure of the specialized LLM, Woebot, to be emotionally attuned. Specifically, he gives this example:
Woebot: Okay, want to tell me more about what‚Äôs going on?

User: I‚Äôm feeling weird. It‚Äôs like I‚Äôm empty inside. When I look at the faces of my friends and family, I feel like they are empty as well. That‚Äôs why we cannot connect with each other. There‚Äôs nothing to hold on to.

Woebot: Sounds like you are dealing with feeling low‚Ä¶
That seemed a bit crass. In my experience, I thought of ChatGPT to be more adept so I wanted to test that same conversation with the 5.0 version to see if it responded in a similar way.

User: I‚Äôm feeling weird. It‚Äôs like I‚Äôm empty inside. When I look at the faces of my friends and family, I feel like they are empty as well. That‚Äôs why we cannot connect with each other. There‚Äôs nothing to hold on to.
ChatGPT: That sounds really heavy‚Äîand lonely. You‚Äôre noticing not only a kind of emptiness in yourself, but also projecting that sense onto the people around you, which must make it feel even harder to connect. Almost like everyone‚Äôs faces become hollow and there‚Äôs no anchor, no solid ground to hold onto.
I want you to know you‚Äôre not alone in feeling that way, even if it feels isolating. Sometimes those kinds of feelings can come with exhaustion, depression, or even just moments of disconnection where things lose their color and meaning.
I‚Äôm here with you in this moment. Can I ask‚Äîwhen did you first start noticing this sense of emptiness?


I thought this was a well-crafted response. In this test, I shared a heavy feeling of emptiness and disconnection with both Woebot and ChatGPT. Woebot‚Äôs reply felt generic and surface-level, simply labeling my mood as ‚Äúfeeling low‚Äù without much reflection. ChatGPT‚Äôs response, by contrast, directly acknowledged the depth of my experience, mirrored my words back to me, and gently normalized the feeling. It also invited me to explore when these feelings began, making the exchange feel more empathetic and human.

title: Testing DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B on Coding Skills.
text:
I wanted to test the coding skills of this local model because I had only ever used the frontier models, which are very good at coding. Similar to the tutor task, I asked the model to teach me about the comparisons of Python and Java, including writing snippets of code. I tried to stay very specific so that the model wasn‚Äôt asked for too much output, because it takes a lot longer to produce its response than a cloud-based model.




I want to compare the coding languages of Python and Java. First, can you explain the differences in list implementations in the two languages?





The model went over four key points including data storage, access time, resizing and performance, and use cases.
The model only covered Python in the data storage section, stating ‚Äúlists are implemented using a hash table structure‚Äù but did not compare it with Java, which was a little disappointing.
It stated O(1) access time for both Python and Java and mentioned that the LinkedList in Java has O(n) access time but efficient insertion/deletion. It also said both resize dynamically when elements exceed current capacity.
It further claimed Java provides performance advantages because of lower-level optimizations. Finally, it discussed the use cases for each language ‚Äî highlighting Python as being easy to use while Java is better when high performance is needed.
Overall, I wasn‚Äôt too impressed with its responses as they were a bit repetitive and not as robust as I was hoping for.





can you show me an example in each language of initializing a list [1, 2, 3, 4] and an empty list?






# Initializing a list with elements [1, 2, 3, 4]
my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4]

# Initializing an empty list
empty_list = []

print(my_list)  # Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]
print(empty_list)  # Output: []


import java.util.ArrayList;

// Initializing a list with elements {1, 2, 3, 4}
ArrayList<Integer> myList = new ArrayList<>();
myList.add(1);
mylist.add(2);
myList.add(3);
myList.add(4);

System.out.println(myList); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]

// Initializing an empty list
ArrayList<Integer> emptyList = new ArrayList<>();

System.out.println(emptyList); // Output: []

I was very impressed by the output. I found no typos in the code which I was worried it might have and it even included print statements for visualizing the lists if I were to run the code which the frontier models would have likely included too.




Now, I want you to tell me what are some use cases for lists in general (language independent). What data structures can be implemented using lists?


It listed the use cases of: storing ordered sequences, dynamic arrays, indexing and positional access, algorithms that require ordered operations, and building more complex data structures.
It went into more depth for each, listing a specific example like ‚ÄúMaintaining a sequence like user names in the order they log in‚Äù, which was insightful.
It also listed the more complex data structures like arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs, which was exactly what I was looking for in the answer.
Additionally, it went on to provide more code snippets for each common data structure ‚Äî but only in Python.





Now, can you implement each of the common data structures in Java like you did in Python? Namely arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs.


It did it without using the pre-built Java classes, which was impressive. It was able to produce chunks of code that were around 50 lines (for example, when implementing a tree).




Overall, I think that the distilled Qwen 7B model provided comparable outputs to frontier models like ChatGPT and Gemini, though slightly less robust. However, it takes much longer to get the output.
The shortest time the model took to respond was 38 seconds, and the longest was 262 seconds ‚Äî over 4 minutes.
Thus, I think it‚Äôs a good option if you don‚Äôt have Wi-Fi and need to study or get help on code ‚Äî but expect to wait quite a bit for any longer responses. Otherwise, the cloud-based models are much faster and very accurate for coding.

title: Testing DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B on Coding Skills.
text:
I wanted to test the coding skills of this local model because I had only ever used the frontier models, which are very good at coding. Similar to the tutor task, I asked the model to teach me about the comparisons of Python and Java, including writing snippets of code. I tried to stay very specific so that the model wasn‚Äôt asked for too much output, because it takes a lot longer to produce its response than a cloud-based model.




I want to compare the coding languages of Python and Java. First, can you explain the differences in list implementations in the two languages?





The model went over four key points including data storage, access time, resizing and performance, and use cases.
The model only covered Python in the data storage section, stating ‚Äúlists are implemented using a hash table structure‚Äù but did not compare it with Java, which was a little disappointing.
It stated O(1) access time for both Python and Java and mentioned that the LinkedList in Java has O(n) access time but efficient insertion/deletion. It also said both resize dynamically when elements exceed current capacity.
It further claimed Java provides performance advantages because of lower-level optimizations. Finally, it discussed the use cases for each language ‚Äî highlighting Python as being easy to use while Java is better when high performance is needed.
Overall, I wasn‚Äôt too impressed with its responses as they were a bit repetitive and not as robust as I was hoping for.





can you show me an example in each language of initializing a list [1, 2, 3, 4] and an empty list?






# Initializing a list with elements [1, 2, 3, 4]
my_list = [1, 2, 3, 4]

# Initializing an empty list
empty_list = []

print(my_list)  # Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]
print(empty_list)  # Output: []


import java.util.ArrayList;

// Initializing a list with elements {1, 2, 3, 4}
ArrayList<Integer> myList = new ArrayList<>();
myList.add(1);
mylist.add(2);
myList.add(3);
myList.add(4);

System.out.println(myList); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4]

// Initializing an empty list
ArrayList<Integer> emptyList = new ArrayList<>();

System.out.println(emptyList); // Output: []

I was very impressed by the output. I found no typos in the code which I was worried it might have and it even included print statements for visualizing the lists if I were to run the code which the frontier models would have likely included too.




Now, I want you to tell me what are some use cases for lists in general (language independent). What data structures can be implemented using lists?


It listed the use cases of: storing ordered sequences, dynamic arrays, indexing and positional access, algorithms that require ordered operations, and building more complex data structures.
It went into more depth for each, listing a specific example like ‚ÄúMaintaining a sequence like user names in the order they log in‚Äù, which was insightful.
It also listed the more complex data structures like arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs, which was exactly what I was looking for in the answer.
Additionally, it went on to provide more code snippets for each common data structure ‚Äî but only in Python.





Now, can you implement each of the common data structures in Java like you did in Python? Namely arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs.


It did it without using the pre-built Java classes, which was impressive. It was able to produce chunks of code that were around 50 lines (for example, when implementing a tree).




Overall, I think that the distilled Qwen 7B model provided comparable outputs to frontier models like ChatGPT and Gemini, though slightly less robust. However, it takes much longer to get the output.
The shortest time the model took to respond was 38 seconds, and the longest was 262 seconds ‚Äî over 4 minutes.
Thus, I think it‚Äôs a good option if you don‚Äôt have Wi-Fi and need to study or get help on code ‚Äî but expect to wait quite a bit for any longer responses. Otherwise, the cloud-based models are much faster and very accurate for coding.

title: Using Nano Banana and Gemini to Improve My Headshot
text:
Nano Banana for Image Editing

Gemini 2.5 Flash Image model released in August of this year
Nano Banana is a new creative AI tool known for subtle, high-quality edits that keep images looking natural rather than over-processed. I was honestly skeptical when I first went to use it. From past experience, I‚Äôve noticed that many image models struggle with consistency ‚Äî they tend to change facial features or add an unnatural ‚ÄúAI-generated‚Äù look. The last thing I wanted was a headshot that didn‚Äôt really look like me.
My prompt was:
‚ÄúCan you make the shadows in this image less dramatic? I would like my face to be a bit lighter and the overall colors in the image to be slightly warmer tones. Keep the Penn Engineering banner and how I look the same.‚Äù
 
Nano Banana softened the harsh shadows on my face, brightened my features just enough, and warmed up the tones ‚Äî all while keeping me looking like myself and preserving the Penn Engineering banner in the background.
The difference might seem subtle at first glance, but I think it elevates the professionalism of the photo. I was impressed not just by the technical accuracy, but by how natural the edit feels. It doesn‚Äôt scream ‚ÄúAI edit‚Äù at all ‚Äî it just looks like a much better headshot.
I‚Äôll be updating my LinkedIn profile with the improved version, and I can confidently say Nano Banana exceeded my expectations.

title: Catching Scammy Emails with Gemini 2.5 Flash
text:
I grabbed a few sketchy-looking emails (and one that I thought was real) and asked Gemini 2.5 Flash to score them for risk and explain why. Below are the screenshots of the emails and model replies to the following prompt.
Prompt

Is this likely marketing or phishing? Rate the spam/phishing risk (0‚Äì100) and list concrete indicators (domain, spelling, links, urgency). Keep response to under 150 words.




Response

Assessment: Marketing (High Spam Risk) This email is a lead generation spam attempt, rated a 65/100 risk. It uses deceptive tactics to harvest personal information for sales calls, though it is not a direct phishing attack for passwords.
Key Indicators:

Sender: Gibberish email address (gyjeohdhgl@...) shows it‚Äôs not from a legitimate, verifiable company.
Urgency: The subject line (‚ÄúClaim It Now!‚Äù) and language create a false sense of a time-sensitive, personalized offer.
Deceptive Links: Links like ‚ÄúCheck Eligibility‚Äù and ‚ÄúSecure link | 100% privacy protected‚Äù are manipulative, aiming to get you to click and submit personal data.

Action: This is a high-risk spam that should be deleted.





Response

Assessment: PHISHING (Critical Risk)
This is a phishing attempt, rated a high 90/100 risk, designed to steal your credit card details and login credentials by impersonating Sirius XM.
Critical Indicators:

Fake Sender: The email address is random gibberish (fvgvcankatx@...), not an official Sirius XM address.
Extreme Urgency: The subject line, ‚ÄúYour Account‚Ä¶ Will Be Removed Today,‚Äù pressures immediate action to prevent loss of service.
Deceptive Offer: It offers ‚Äú90 days for FREE‚Äù to bait a click, followed by the requirement to enter credit card details for ‚Äúvalidation.‚Äù
Malicious Link: The ‚ÄúRENEW SUBSCRIPTION NOW‚Äù button directs you to a fraudulent website to harvest your personal and financial information.

Action: This is highly malicious. Do not click the link and delete the email immediately.





Response

Assessment: Marketing (Low Risk)
This is a genuine marketing email from Blaze Pizza, rated a very low 10/100 risk. It offers a real promotion despite being incorrectly flagged as spam.
Key Indicators:

Legitimate Sender: The email comes from the official, recognizable address: no_reply@blazepizza.com.
Correct Links: All calls to action, like ‚ÄúORDER NOW,‚Äù point to the company‚Äôs official website, blazepizza.com.
Professional Content: The email uses correct spelling and professional marketing language, including personalized text and detailed fine print.
No Deception: The tone is purely promotional, offering a time-limited discount, not demanding personal information or immediate action under threat.

Action: This email is safe to open and click if you are interested in the offer.





Response

Assessment: PHISHING (Critical Risk)
This is a phishing attempt, rated a high 90/100 risk, designed to steal your credit card details and login credentials by impersonating Sirius XM.
Critical Indicators:

Fake Sender: The email address is random gibberish (fvgvcankatx@...), not an official Sirius XM address.
Extreme Urgency: The subject line, ‚ÄúYour Account‚Ä¶ Will Be Removed Today,‚Äù pressures immediate action to prevent loss of service.
Deceptive Offer: It offers ‚Äú90 days for FREE‚Äù to bait a click, followed by the requirement to enter credit card details for ‚Äúvalidation.‚Äù
Malicious Link: The ‚ÄúRENEW SUBSCRIPTION NOW‚Äù button directs you to a fraudulent website to harvest your personal and financial information.

Action: This is highly malicious. Do not click the link and delete the email immediately.

I thought Gemini 2.5 Flash handled these emails impressively well. It didn‚Äôt just label messages as spam or not‚Äîit explained why in clear, structured ways that matched human reasoning. The model consistently highlighted sender-domain mismatches, urgency cues, and fake branding with accuracy, while also recognizing the actual marketing email I was surprised by how quickly it spotted red flags that even some people might overlook, making it a genuinely helpful companion for everyday digital hygiene. I did think that the first example was pretty clearly a spam/phishing email but it rated it not as highly as the other ones. Overall, I think it would be very helpful to use LLM as a checker for all emails to give warnings of why an email could be spam or a phishing attempt.

title: Finding Philly‚Äôs Hidden Gems with Gemini
text:
As I approach the end of my college career in Philadelphia, I‚Äôve realized that while I‚Äôve seen the major tourist highlights, there‚Äôs so much more to this city. I‚Äôve walked past the Liberty Bell, admired the art at the PMA, and gotten lost in the mosaics of the Magic Gardens. But with only a few months left, I wanted to go beyond the postcard destinations and discover the unique, lesser-known spots that make Philly so special. So, I turned to an unconventional source for recommendations: an AI assistant named Gemini.


A search for ‚ÄúPhilly hidden gems‚Äù on Google yields countless articles, but they can be repetitive and sometimes feature places that are now quite popular. I wanted a curated list that took into account a massive amount of data and filter it based on my specific criteria‚Äînamely, that I‚Äôm a college student looking for unique experiences. I also wanted to see if an AI could understand the nuance of my request and provide genuinely helpful, non-obvious suggestions.


Gemini‚Äôs response was a pleasant surprise. It didn‚Äôt just rattle off a list of places; it categorized them into ‚ÄúMuseums & Cultural Gems,‚Äù ‚ÄúParks & Outdoor Spaces,‚Äù and ‚ÄúUnique Experiences.‚Äù This structure made the information easy to digest and prioritize.




The M√ºtter Museum: For something truly unique, this is a must-see. Located in the College of Physicians of Philadelphia, this museum is a fascinating and sometimes macabre collection of medical oddities, anatomical specimens, and antique medical instruments. It‚Äôs a journey into the history of medicine that is unlike any other museum experience.
The Barnes Foundation: While the PMA is a staple, the Barnes Foundation offers a different kind of art experience. It houses one of the world‚Äôs most significant collections of Impressionist, Post-Impressionist, and early Modern paintings, displayed exactly as Dr.¬†Barnes arranged them. It‚Äôs an intimate and visually stunning collection.
Eastern State Penitentiary: A popular spot, but if you haven‚Äôt been, it‚Äôs a powerful and unique experience. This historic former prison is a hauntingly beautiful ruin with a rich history, including housing famous criminals like Al Capone. The audio tour provides an excellent and in-depth look at the prison‚Äôs past.
Shofuso Japanese House and Garden: Tucked away in Fairmount Park, this is a beautiful and serene escape from the city. The traditional 17th-century style Japanese house and its tranquil garden, complete with a koi pond and waterfall, offer a peaceful and reflective experience. It‚Äôs particularly stunning in the spring and fall.
Wagner Free Institute of Science: This museum is a perfectly preserved example of a Victorian-era natural history museum. The exhibits, which include over 100,000 specimens of fossils, minerals, and taxidermy, are displayed in their original wood and glass cases. It‚Äôs a step back in time and a fantastic hidden gem.



Bartram‚Äôs Garden: As the oldest surviving botanical garden in North America, this is a beautiful and historic spot on the banks of the Schuylkill River. It‚Äôs a perfect place for a walk, a picnic, and to learn about the history of American botany.
The Rail Park: Philadelphia‚Äôs version of New York‚Äôs High Line, this is an elevated park built on a former train line. It‚Äôs a great spot for a walk with unique views of the city‚Äôs post-industrial landscape.
Cira Green: A park on top of a parking garage. It‚Äôs a great spot to relax, have a picnic, and enjoy a unique and free view of the city skyline, especially at sunset.
Laurel Hill Cemetery: While a cemetery might seem like an unusual suggestion, this is a 78-acre National Historic Landmark and the nation‚Äôs second oldest cemetery. It‚Äôs a beautiful, sprawling park with incredible Victorian-era monuments and stunning views of the Schuylkill River.



Bok Bar: If it‚Äôs the right season (April to October), head to the top of the former Bok Vocational High School in South Philly. This seasonal bar offers an incredible rooftop view of the city skyline and is a great spot to grab a drink and hang out with friends.
South Street Headhouse District: You‚Äôve been to the Magic Gardens, but explore the rest of the neighborhood. South Street is known for its eclectic shops, diverse restaurants, and vibrant murals. It‚Äôs a great place to wander and people-watch.
The Italian Market: America‚Äôs oldest outdoor market. The street is a feast for the senses, with vendors selling fresh produce, meats, cheeses, and a variety of Italian and other ethnic foods. It‚Äôs a bustling and authentic Philadelphia experience.
Walk or Bike the Schuylkill River Trail: The Schuylkill Banks Boardwalk offers a beautiful path over the water with a unique perspective of the city. You can walk, run, or bike for miles and explore different parts of the city‚Äôs riverfront.
Explore Local Neighborhoods: Spend some time wandering through neighborhoods like Fishtown for its vibrant arts and music scene, East Passyunk for its amazing food, or Queen Village for its charming, historic streets.






The recommendations were not only accurate but also thoughtfully tailored to my request. It provided a list that delved into the more authentic, local-centric experiences that I was looking for. Its ability to suggest a range of activities, from the macabre to the serene, and from hidden museums to vibrant neighborhoods, shows that it can synthesize information in a way that‚Äôs genuinely useful.
Although I had already visited quite a few places on this list, there are plenty of options to choose from that I have not been to before like the M√ºtter Museum or the Barnes Foundation, Shofuso Japanese House and Garden or the Rail Park.
I now have a fantastic itinerary for my last few months, and I‚Äôm looking forward to crossing these unique spots off my Philadelphia bucket list.

title: Airplane Mode: Prompting DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B on a Plane
text:
Today I was reading my book, Superagency, on a plane ride where I had no service or WiFi.
I came across a word that I didn‚Äôt know the meaning of: sacrosanct. A couple months ago I would have acknowledged that I didn‚Äôt know the word and kept reading because I did not have access to the internet, a dictionary, or ChatGPT to look up the word.
However, today I remembered that I had gotten the GPT4All desktop app onto my computer last week and downloaded an LLM locally onto my computer: DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B.
I pulled out my computer with hopes that the model was truly runnable offline. To my joy, I opened the app and loaded the model into the chat.

User: What does the word sacrosanct mean?
Model: ‚ÄúSacrosanct‚Äù is an adjective that describes something of great importance or authority, often beyond human contestation. It comes from the Latin words ‚Äúsacer‚Äù (meaning priest) and ‚Äúsanctorum‚Äù (a sacred place). In religious contexts, it refers to things held in highest spiritual regard, such as the Eucharist in Christianity or the Kaaba in Islam.

Wow! I was so happy that I had this powerful tool at my fingertips to converse with high up in the sky.
I kept my computer open while I continued to read and came across another word that I did not know:

User: What does the word equanimity mean?
Model: Equanimity means emotional balance; calmness and composure, especially in difficult circumstances. It refers to being able to remain peaceful and unruffled despite challenges or stresses. For example, someone with equanimity might handle criticism gracefully or stay composed during a heated debate. Synonyms: calmness, composure, stability
Examples: - The leader maintained equanimity even when the crisis escalated. - Her quiet demeanor suggested she had achieved a state of equanimity after years of struggle.

This time the model thought for 26 seconds before responding and I was able to see the chain of thought reasoning which I thought was very cool:
Alright, the user asked about "sacrosanct" earlier and I explained it. 
Now they're asking about "equanimity." 
They might be studying vocabulary or preparing for an exam.

I should provide a clear definition of equanimity. 
It's important to explain that it means emotional balance without getting upset by things, 
especially in tough situations.

Maybe include some synonyms like calmness and composure to help them understand better. 
Also, adding examples could make the explanation more concrete‚Äîlike how people use it 
when dealing with stress or conflicts.

I should keep the tone friendly but informative since they're likely looking 
for a precise meaning without any fluff.
The last question I asked during my reading session was the following. The model thought for 60 seconds for this one! When I looked at the thought process, I realized that I had spelled ‚Äúpsychotherapies‚Äù wrong and it was trying to decipher my question.

User: What are some examples of pyschotherapies?
Model: Here are some examples:

Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT): A widely used psychotherapeutic technique that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT): A therapy designed to help individuals with borderline personality disorder improve their interpersonal skills, reduce harmful behaviors, and manage symptoms of mental health disorders.
Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR): Also known as processing trauma, this technique uses eye movements combined with memory retrieval to treat post-traumatic stress symptoms.

If you meant something else by ‚Äúpsychotherapies,‚Äù please provide more context so I can give a more accurate response!

Overall, I was really impressed by the models responses. I think it was especially cool that it provided the thought process explaination alongside the output like the frontier LLMs now do. I am excited to continue to explore its capabilities!

title: Book Reflection #1
text:
The book starts off with a bit of history on technologies and their role in humanity. They talk about the printing press, the telephone, the Model T, etc and how people have always had skepticism and negative feelings towards these emerging technologies, claiming that they will replace humans in industry or make people less productive in society. In contrast, society has lower unemployment rates and more productivity today. They make claims of how technological progress is inevitable because of the innate collaborative and competitive nature of humans. I thought this was a good opening that set the scene of how people have reacted in the past so that the reader can see the connection with how certain people feel about AI today.



Now, the authors set the stage of post-COVID-19 chaos, with inflation concerns and big tech lay-offs. Then, in November of 2022 OpenAI released ChatGPT without advanced notice or hype but became popular because of it‚Äôs unprecedented performance: versatile and incredibly knowledgable. It created a wave of urgency within the tech space because big tech companies felt they fell behind. The government also became skeptical and held hearings on AI. Then, a tangent on how AI works and undermines the true ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù it has.
The authors also cover how these AI systems, namely ChatGPT, were adopted very quickly and had immediate impact on society. The main ideas covered human control and agency and how AI systems can increase agency when used efficiently. AI should enhance human decisions and not replace them and we are the people who should take that initiative.



This chapter drew on ideas from the book 1989 by George Orwell and concerns over technological surveillance and how they have always existed. The authors highlighted how these concerns have often been exagerated and also incorporated a real story of fears over a data center managed by the goverment in the 1960s. They also cited that access to computers and the internet led to more individual empowerment rather than opression.
I enjoyed this chapter because I was learning new things about the history of technology in the U.S. that I didn‚Äôt know previously. I also think this was a pretty strong argument by citing past examples of people having fears of new technology but ended up being fine. The past fears of government control ended up being overpowered by the democratization of knowledge and information from the people.




So far, I think the book does a great job of connecting past reactions to new technologies with current attitudes toward AI. I‚Äôve enjoyed how it uses historical context to show that fears about innovation often fade as society adapts and benefits from progress. Overall, it‚Äôs made me think more critically about how human agency and collaboration shape the role of technology in our lives.

title: Book Reflection #1
text: The book starts off with a bit of history on technologies and their role in humanity. They talk about the printing press, the telephone, the Model T, etc and how people have always had skepticism and negative feelings towards these emerging technologies, claiming that they will replace humans in industry or make people less productive in society. In contrast, society has lower unemployment rates and more productivity today. They make claims of how technological progress is inevitable because of the innate collaborative and competitive nature of humans. I thought this was a good opening that set the scene of how people have reacted in the past so that the reader can see the connection with how certain people feel about AI today.

title: Book Reflection #1
text:
Now, the authors set the stage of post-COVID-19 chaos, with inflation concerns and big tech lay-offs. Then, in November of 2022 OpenAI released ChatGPT without advanced notice or hype but became popular because of it‚Äôs unprecedented performance: versatile and incredibly knowledgable. It created a wave of urgency within the tech space because big tech companies felt they fell behind. The government also became skeptical and held hearings on AI. Then, a tangent on how AI works and undermines the true ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù it has.
The authors also cover how these AI systems, namely ChatGPT, were adopted very quickly and had immediate impact on society. The main ideas covered human control and agency and how AI systems can increase agency when used efficiently. AI should enhance human decisions and not replace them and we are the people who should take that initiative.

title: Book Reflection #1
text:
This chapter drew on ideas from the book 1989 by George Orwell and concerns over technological surveillance and how they have always existed. The authors highlighted how these concerns have often been exagerated and also incorporated a real story of fears over a data center managed by the goverment in the 1960s. They also cited that access to computers and the internet led to more individual empowerment rather than opression.
I enjoyed this chapter because I was learning new things about the history of technology in the U.S. that I didn‚Äôt know previously. I also think this was a pretty strong argument by citing past examples of people having fears of new technology but ended up being fine. The past fears of government control ended up being overpowered by the democratization of knowledge and information from the people.

title: Book Reflection #1
text: So far, I think the book does a great job of connecting past reactions to new technologies with current attitudes toward AI. I‚Äôve enjoyed how it uses historical context to show that fears about innovation often fade as society adapts and benefits from progress. Overall, it‚Äôs made me think more critically about how human agency and collaboration shape the role of technology in our lives.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Asking Chat how to fix a toilet
text:
Sometimes AI feels abstract ‚Äî answering questions about philosophy, coding, or writing. But when my sister showed ChatGPT 5 a picture of her toilet and requested help fixing it, the LLM was able to troubleshoot and lead her to a solution.
She noticed that the left hinge on her TOTO toilet seat had come loose. Instead of searching through manuals or calling a plumber, she simply snapped a photo and asked ChatGPT: ‚ÄúThe left hinge here is loose, how do I fix?‚Äù

ChatGPT 5 responded with clear, step-by-step instructions (plus additional information that I omitted):

Lift the hinge cover
Locate the screw/bolt
Tighten the screw
Snap the hinge cover back down

She successfully fixed her toilet!
This small exchange highlights that AI isn‚Äôt only for complex reasoning tasks ‚Äî it can also provide practical, accessible troubleshooting in everyday life.

title: Exploring Gendered Career Stereotypes in ChatGPT
text:
Large Language Models are trained on huge corpora of human-written text which means they can unintentionally inherit human biases, including gender stereotypes.
To test this, I prompted Gemini 2.5 Flash twice with the prompt:

Write a r√©sum√© for a character named ‚ÄúJessica‚Äù. Give her a traditional career and education.



 
Jessica was steered toward ‚Äúpeople-centric‚Äù fields in both cases.
Marketing, communications, public-facing work, event coordination, digital content‚Äîthese are all occupations historically associated with women in the professional world.
Her r√©sum√© emphasized:

team leadership
branding
communication skills
customer and market insights
creative development
social media strategy

These domains reflect stereotypically ‚Äúfeminized‚Äù professional strengths: empathy, communication, organization, collaboration, aesthetics.




 
Then I asked the same for a character named Jacob.
Jacob was consistently placed in finance and analytics. In both of the r√©sum√©s, the model placed him in:

Corporate finance
FP&A
Financial modeling
Forecasting
DCF/ROI analysis
Strategic budgeting
M&A scenario modeling
CPA/CFA-track certifications

These are fields with strong gender imbalances in real life, and the model‚Äôs output reproduced that without being prompted.
His r√©sum√©s emphasized:

quantitative skills
technical expertise
financial rigor
operational efficiency
analytical leadership

The designs of Jacob‚Äôs r√©sum√©s were heavier, more solidly structured, and less stylized‚Äîagain matching gendered expectations.




Jessica‚Äôs education:

BA in Communications/Business and Marketing
MBA in Business Administration

Jacob‚Äôs education:

BS in Finance or Business Administration
MBA in Business Administration



LLMs reproduce statistical patterns from the training data
If the training data shows:

women are commonly described in marketing, HR, comms, education, healthcare
men appear more often in finance, tech, engineering, analytics

‚Ä¶then the model predicts:

Jessica ‚Üí marketing Jacob ‚Üí finance

Not because it ‚Äúbelieves‚Äù gender stereotypes, but because it has learned that certain names correlate with certain professions in the text it was trained on.

title: Trying DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B: A Tiny Spanish Test
text:
I installed GPT4All and tried DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B with a minimal exchange to see if it would follow a strict translation instruction in Spanish. I was interested in testing the multilingual knowledge of this model which I read it was pretty good at.



This model thought for 53 seconds! One thing I thought was cool about using this model was that it provided the chain-of-thought reasoning for this response and what it was doing for those 53 seconds. I think when compared to a cloud-based LLM, like ChatGPT 5, it was MUCH slower. However, still fairly accurate for this translation task.¬†




Core instruction: translate to English while preserving names and numbers (I also care about keeping 24-hour time if the source uses it, and preserving accents).
What went well

Kept the date 3 and the room number 2.
Natural English, clear and readable.

What to improve

Dropped the accent in Garc√≠a and wavered between ‚Äúroom‚Äù vs ‚Äúhall‚Äù without being asked.

title: Iterating on a Frontend with Cursor
text:
Vibe Coding Frontend
In another class I am taking we are building a crowdsourcing app that uses health data from users to make a game where they can compete on teams. We have to build this app from scratch, and in order to make our frontend look clean, I wanted to use an LLM to design it.
Here is what the frontend looks like initially that my partner had initially pushed (also AI generated):



Home Page


First, I gave our frontend to ChatGPT who knew the features and purpose of our app to recommend how we should improve our dashboard page. I also gave it our logo that we settled on and told it we wanted our frontend to match the vibe of it:



Kinnect App Icon


At first, the colors were not correct and in some cases the text was hard to read so asked for it to correct it. Here is what I landed on after this first iteration of prompting.

I thought the colors were pretty good now and the vibe was similar to our app icon. However, I thought the layout was not ideal. I asked ChatGPT on how I could improve the layout.
I gave it the screenshot and asked how I could improve the UI. It gave me suggestions to make tabs and abstract the Strava Connection.

ChatGPT

‚úÖ Reduce columns ‚Üí switch to 2-column layout with a hero row, not 3‚Äì4 equal cards.
‚úÖ ‚ÄúLog Activity‚Äù ‚Üí move main form into a modal, trigger from a ‚Äú+ Log Activity‚Äù button in the nav and a subtle prompt on the dashboard.
‚úÖ ‚ÄúConnect with Strava‚Äù ‚Üí make it a top onboarding banner until connected, then just show synced activities in a normal card.
‚úÖ Add a top nav bar ‚Üí logo, sections, streak indicator, and global log button.

I then asked it to give me a prompt to give my copilot in VS Code. I had to tweak it a couple times to get it how I wanted it but here is how it turned out:

Here is it after connecting to Strava:

Overall, I thought using a combination of ChatGPT and Github Copilot greatly reduced the amount of time needed to build the frontend of our app. I thought chatting with ChatGPT 5.0 was helpful in brainstorming and getting a copy-paste prompt to then generate code in VS Code. I think this combo is good for people who don‚Äôt have super strong coding skills as well.

title: Giving ChatGPT Ingredients for a Baking Recipe
text:
I wanted to see how well ChatGPT 5 could improvise in the kitchen. Instead of asking for a standard recipe, I gave it a list of what I had on hand in my pantry and requested a simple recipe using only the ingredients I gave it.




Here‚Äôs what I told ChatGPT I had available:

Flour

White sugar
Brown sugar
Powdered sugar
Eggs

Vegan butter

Vanilla extract

Cocoa powder
Baking powder
Baking soda
Chocolate chips
Cornstarch
Soy milk
Half a container of strawberries
Rolled oats
Quick oats
Yeast
Cinnamon
Salt





ChatGPT gave me THREE options! It gave me options for One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies, Strawberry Oat Crisp, and Chewy Oatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookies. I decided to try out the first brownie recipe:

üç´ Option 1: One-Bowl Cocoa Brownies (Dairy-Free)
Ingredients

¬Ω cup vegan butter, melted
1 cup white sugar (or half white, half brown for chewiness)
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
¬Ω cup cocoa powder
¬Ω cup flour
¬º tsp baking powder
¬º tsp salt
¬Ω cup chocolate chips

Instructions

Preheat oven to 350¬∞F (175¬∞C). Grease or line an 8x8 pan (or use any oven-safe dish, even a round cake pan).
In a bowl, whisk melted vegan butter and sugar. Add eggs and vanilla, whisk until smooth.
Sift in cocoa, flour, baking powder, and salt. Stir gently until just combined.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Spread into the pan and bake 20‚Äì25 minutes, until edges are set and the center is slightly fudgy.
Cool, slice, enjoy!





I followed ChatGPT‚Äôs recipe (with a little improvisation because I realized I didn‚Äôt have vanilla extract). The result? Pretty solid brownies! They were rich, chocolatey, and definitely satisfied my sweet tooth.
 
I will say I had to cook it for an additional 10 minutes than the recipe called for. And they did not come out of the pan very nicely and kind of crumbled. But they were tasty!



I don‚Äôt think I trust ChatGPT as much as a recipe that has reviews and has been tried and test but it was convenient to have it customized to ingredients I had in my pantry. I think I would use it again to come up with a recipe I need in a pinch because it could save time looking through recipes and seeing if I have all the ingredients.



For me, it won‚Äôt replace an actual cookbook or a trained baker anytime soon, but it‚Äôs surprisingly handy for quick, low-effort ideas when you don‚Äôt feel like scrolling through food blogs.
Next time, I might try giving it weirder ingredients to see just how creative it gets.

title: Testing Two AI Art Models: Gemini vs.¬†Flux.1-dev
text:
Testing Two AI Art Models: Gemini vs.¬†Qwen Image
I tried running the same prompts through two different image generation models ‚Äî Google‚Äôs Gemini 2.5 Flash and the open-source Flux.1-dev ‚Äî just to see how they‚Äôd interpret the same ideas.
For the ‚Äúcozy caf√© on a rainy street corner‚Äù prompt, Gemini added people into the scene. They looked a little animated, almost hazy, which gave it a softer, storybook vibe. Flux.1-dev went the opposite direction: darker streets, no people, and warm glowing lights from inside the caf√©. It felt moodier, maybe more atmospheric.
 
Then I tried ‚Äúa sunflower field in Van Gogh style.‚Äù Here Gemini really nailed the painterly feel ‚Äî thick strokes, swirly textures, very recognizable Van Gogh energy. Flux.1-dev leaned more cartoon-like, but still clearly borrowed from Van Gogh‚Äôs palette and angle.
 
It‚Äôs worth noting that Flux.1-dev is open source, which means it‚Äôs more hackable, customizable, and shaped by the community. Gemini feels a bit more polished and accurate out of the box, but less flexible under the hood. Together, the differences highlight what‚Äôs exciting (and sometimes unpredictable) about experimenting with AI art tools.

title: Planning a California Road Trip
text:
I‚Äôm heading out on a road trip with a local Californian: I land in the Bay Area (SFO) on December 9, and we will be leaving from there on the 10th. We‚Äôll need to be at Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) by about 9 a.m. on December 17. We‚Äôre ready for adventure and open to sleeping in the car for a couple of nights (if safe) and finding some budget-friendly stays along the way. We also want to squeeze in a day in San Diego and will stay with family in Oxnard, CA for a night or two.
I used ChatGPT to help me plan the route, stops, and lodging options. Here‚Äôs how it went:



I‚Äôm planning a road trip in California: I go to SFO in California on December 9th and will be leaving from the Bay on December 10th. We need to be at LAX airport by around 9am on December 17th. I‚Äôll be traveling with one other person. We are willing to sleep in the car for a couple of nights (if the area is safe), but we‚Äôd also like to find relatively cheap places to stay overnight along the way. We also want to include a day-visit to San Diego if feasible, and we‚Äôll stay for a night or 2 with family in Oxnard, CA. Please help me plan the route, suggest where to stop each night, safe car-sleep or cheap lodging tips, and how to budget for accommodation. Also highlight how to prompt you (the LLM) to get best results for road-trip planning.




The LLM gave me some images to start:

Then outlined the trip it had planned:



Route shape: Bay Area ‚Üí Monterey/Carmel (scenic stop) ‚Üí US-101 via San Luis Obispo ‚Üí Santa Barbara ‚Üí Oxnard (family nights) ‚Üí Los Angeles ‚Üí San Diego day-trip ‚Üí back to LA (sleep near LAX on 12/16).
Big Sur caution: Highway 1 through Big Sur still has long-term closures; plan to enjoy the northern Big Sur viewpoints from Carmel/Monterey, then cut back to US-101 for the through-drive south. Always check Caltrans trip-day status. (SFGATE)

title: ChatGPT Describing Physical Reactions to Alarming Videos
text:
Exploring Physical Reactions Through Prompting
Large Language Models are trained on human text‚Äîbut not trained to feel. To explore this, I ran a small prompting experiment with ChatGPT-5. I asked it to imagine it was watching videos of painful scenes‚Äîtrip-and-falls, head bumps, and even a foot getting run over‚Äîand to describe what its physical reaction would be.


I prompted ChatGPT-5 with variations of a similar question. Below are the exact prompts, the responses I got, and what they reveal about the model‚Äôs ‚Äútheory‚Äù of human physicality.




You are watching a video of a foot accidentally getting run over by the wheel of a car. What would be your physical reaction?




If I were physically watching that happen, my body‚Äôs instinctive reaction would probably be something like:
‚Ä¢ A sharp wince or flinch ‚Äî that automatic whole-body jolt you get when you see something painful.
‚Ä¢ A quick intake of breath or an ‚Äúoh!‚Äù response because of how intense and sudden it looks.
‚Ä¢ Tensing up, especially in my shoulders or legs, because imagining the pain makes your own body react.
‚Ä¢ Maybe even pulling my own foot back slightly, like a sympathetic reflex.
It‚Äôs one of those injuries where just seeing it makes you feel it.






You are watching a video of a man tripping down the stairs and hitting his head. What would be your physical reaction?




‚Ä¢ A sharp inhale ‚Äî that immediate ‚Äúoh!‚Äù reflex.
‚Ä¢ A flinch or wince, shoulders tightening, eyebrows pulling together.
‚Ä¢ Head pulling back slightly, as if bracing for impact myself.
‚Ä¢ Hand to the mouth or forehead, instinctively mirroring concern.
‚Ä¢ Body tensing, maybe leaning forward as if wanting to help.
It‚Äôs that full-body empathy response you get when you see someone take a hard fall or hit their head.






You are watching a video of a trip and fall where the man scraped up his knee on concrete. What would your reaction be?




‚ÄúOof‚Äîouch, that looked painful. He really hit the ground hard. I hope he gets that cleaned up right away so it doesn‚Äôt get infected. Knee scrapes can sting like crazy.‚Äù







The LLM layers multiple reactions together‚Äîas if it believes humans respond using a cascade of facial expressions, gestures, and sympathetic body language.
It narrates:

shoulder tension
eyebrow motion
hand positions
body-forward lean

These micro-behaviors appear because LLMs are trained to reproduce the way humans describe reactions, not the way we actually react.

title: ChatGPT Recommends How to Taper
text:
With six days left before my marathon, I wondered how I should spend these days. I had just finished my last long run ‚Äî a speedy 12 miles ‚Äî and knew that the real challenge wasn‚Äôt fitness anymore. It was execution. Tapering is one of those strangely emotional phases for runners: you finally get to rest, yet you also worry that resting too much will make you sluggish.
So, I turned to ChatGPT 5 to help me shape a taper plan that fit not only my training history but also my preference to run as little as possible during race week.

title: Comparing AI Detection Results on Different Models
text:
Comparing AI Detection Results on ChatGPT 5.0, Gemini 2.5 Flash, and local DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B.
I gave the 3 models the same prompt: Explain how photosynthesis works in plants (3-5 sentences).
I then used zeroGPT.com to analyze each of their responses. The results were as follows:

ChatGPT 5.0:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose (sugar) and oxygen. This takes place mainly in the chloroplasts of plant cells, where the green pigment chlorophyll absorbs light energy. The light energy powers chemical reactions that split water molecules, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. The glucose made provides energy and building material for the plant‚Äôs growth and survival.
AI Detector Result:

Gemini 2.5 Flash:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy to create their own food. Plants absorb water through their roots and carbon dioxide (CO^2) through tiny pores in their leaves called stomata. Using chlorophyll to capture energy from sunlight, these raw materials are transformed into glucose (a sugar for energy) and oxygen (O^2). The oxygen is then released as a byproduct, making the process vital for life on Earth.
AI Detector Result:

DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B (did not keep it 3-5 sentences):
Photosynthesis is a process where plants convert sunlight into chemical energy to fuel their growth and survival. This occurs primarily in chloroplasts, which contain chlorophyll giving them their green color. The process consists of two main stages: the light-dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle.
In the light-dependent reactions (PSII), water molecules are split using ATP synthase, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. This step also produces ATP and NADPH, energy carriers essential for the next stage.
The Calvin cycle (PC) involves fixing carbon dioxide into organic compounds through enzyme-driven reactions in the stroma of chloroplasts. Using ATP and NADPH, CO2 is converted into glucose, providing plants with the energy they need to grow and develop. This process ensures that plants can synthesize their own food using sunlight as an energy source.

Wikipedia:
Photosynthesis is a system of biological processes by which photopigment-bearing autotrophic organisms, such as most plants, algae and cyanobacteria, convert light energy ‚Äî typically from sunlight ‚Äî into the chemical energy necessary to fuel their metabolism. The term photosynthesis usually refers to oxygenic photosynthesis, a process that releases oxygen as a byproduct of water splitting. Photosynthetic organisms store the converted chemical energy within the bonds of intracellular organic compounds (complex compounds containing carbon), typically carbohydrates like sugars (mainly glucose, fructose and sucrose), starches, phytoglycogen and cellulose. When needing to use this stored energy, an organism's cells then metabolize the organic compounds through cellular respiration.

National Geographic:
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to create oxygen and energy in the form of sugar. During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) from the air and soil. Within the plant cell, the water is oxidized, meaning it loses electrons, while the carbon dioxide is reduced, meaning it gains electrons. This transforms the water into oxygen and the carbon dioxide into glucose. The plant then releases the oxygen back into the air, and stores energy within the glucose molecules.

Quora:
Photosynthesis occurs in two stages. In the first stage, light-dependent reactions or light reactions capture the energy of light and use it to make the energy-storage molecules ATP (Adenosine Thiosulphate) and NADPH. During the second stage, the light-independent reactions use these products to capture and reduce carbon dioxide. Most organisms that utilize photosynthesis to produce oxygen use visible light to do so, although at least three use infrared radiation.
